cards.question: What is AWS?
cards.answer: Amazon Web Services

cards.question: as
cards.answer: afsfas

cards.question: asf
cards.answer: awd

cards.question: Yo
cards.answer: AVDS

cards.question: compare
cards.answer:
wrasasdf asdfa Zd qwras
asd zxdga asdf qwe
       
       
       
asgd asd z w

cards.question: qwf
cards.answer:
dsgZ as nc
sa asfd zw
asal   qwt

cards.question: Factors for Choosing Region
cards.answer:
• Compliance
  • Proximity to customer
  • Available services
  • Pricing

cards.question: IAM Users & Groups
cards.answer:
Users

  • Can be assigned to IAM Groups
  • Don't have to belong to any IAM Groups
  • Can belong to multiple IAM Groups

Groups

  • Contain IAM Users
  • Cannot be in another IAM Groups

cards.question: IAM Credential Report
cards.answer:
• Account-Level
  • List all of account's users and the status of their credential

cards.question: IAM Acces Advisor
cards.answer:
• User-Level
  • Show permissions granted and when those services are last accessed

cards.question: EC2 Configuration Options
cards.answer:
• Operating System (OS): Linux, Windows, MacOS
  • Compute Power & Cores (CPU)
  • Random Access Memory (RAM
  • Storage Space
    • Network-Attached: (EBS & EFS)
    • Hardware: EC2 Instance Store
  • Network Card: Elastic Network Interface (ENI)
  • Firewall Rules: Security Group
  • Bootstrap Script: EC2 User Data

cards.question: EC2 User Data
cards.answer:
• Launch commands when EC2 instance starts
  • Only run once when instance starts for first time
  • Run with root user privilege

cards.question: EC2 Instance Types
cards.answer:
Instance Type Use Case
General Purpose
  • Web Servers
  • General Workload
Compute Optimized
  • Compute intensived, high performance
  • Batch / High Performance Computing / Machine Learning
Memory Optimized
  • Fast performance on process that require large data in memory
  • In-memory database
Storage Optimized
  • Storage-intensive task, high read/write access 
  • High Frequency Online Transaction (OLTP)

cards.question: Classic Ports
cards.answer:
• 22 = SSH
  • 21 = FTP
  • 22 = SFTP
  • 80 = HTTP
  • 443 = HTTPS
  • 3389 = Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP)

cards.question: EC2 Purchasing Options
cards.answer:
Purchasing Options Description
On-Demand Pay by second
Reserved Instances (Standard) Commit to pay 24/7 for 1 or 3 years, fixed instance family
Reserved Instances (Convertible) Commit to pay 24/7 for 1 or 3 years, can change instance family
Savings Plans Commit to pay certain amount for 1 or 3 years
Spot Instances Short workload, cheapest, interruptable
Dedicated Host Dedicated physical server
Dedicated Instance Dedicated instance but no control over physical server
Capacity Reservation Guarantee compute capacity availability

cards.question: EC2 Dedicated Instance VS Dedicated Host
cards.answer:
Dedicated Instance Dedicated Host
Physical Server Control No Yes
Instance Placement Control No Yes
Licensing Limited licensing support BYOL, licensing per core/socket
Pricing Per instance Per physical host
Complicance For basic isolation For strict compliance

cards.question: EC2 Spot Fleet
cards.answer:
• Set of Spot Instance
  • Launch instances until reach target capacity within price constrain
  • Launch Strategies:
    • PriceCapacityOptimized: Highest capacity available, select pool with lowest price 
    • Lowest Price: Launch instance with lowest price
    • Diversified: Distribute across different launch pools
    • CapacityOptimized: optimal capacity for number of instances

cards.question: EC2 Placement Groups
cards.answer:
Description Pros Cons Use Cases
Cluster Close together on same harware rack Fast, low latency If rack fails, all instance fails Big Data job,
Low latency
Spread Each instance on distinct racks High availability
Reduced risk		 Max 7 instance per AZ High availability,
Isolation
Partition Divide into logical partition. Distinct partition = Distinct racks

Each partition is isolated
Large no. instances

 Max 7 partition per AZ
Instances in same partition are close		 HDFS, Cassandra, Kafka

cards.question: Elastic IP
cards.answer:
• Fixed Public IP for instance
  • Created EIP lasts until user delete (Doesn't expire)
  • Attach to one instance at a time
  • Avoid using Elastic IPs
  • Free: for running instances, NAT Gateway
  • Charged: Unassociated EIP or stopped instances

cards.question: EC2 Hibernate
cards.answer:
• RAM state preserved (data stored in root EBS volume)
  • Instance boot is much faster
  • Root EBS must be encryped
  • Cannot be hibernated >60 days
  • Use Case
    • Long-running process
    • Save RAM state

cards.question: EC2 Instance Store
cards.answer:
• Hardware storage
  • High Performance
  • Lose storage if instance is stopped
  • Use Case
    • High I/O performance
    • Caching
    • Intermediate file processing

cards.question: Security Group
cards.answer:
• STATEFUL
  • Only contain ALLOW rules
  • Regulate:
    • Access to Ports
    • Authorised IP ranges
  • Reference Type:
    • IP address
    • Security Groups (e.g only SG-A can access)
  • Inbound: all traffic blocked by default
  • Outbound: all traffic authorised by default

cards.question: IAM Policy Structure
cards.answer:
Main Structure

  1. Version
  2. ID of Policy (optional)
  3. Statement

Statement

  1. SID: Statement ID (optional)
  2. Effect: ALLOW/DENY
  3. Pricipal: IAM users/groups/roles
  4. Actions: List of actions
  5. Resources: List of Resources
  6. Conditions: For policy to be active (Optional)

cards.question: Elastic Block Storage (EBS)
cards.answer:
• Volume Storage
  • Network Storage
  • Persist data after termination
  • 1 EBS can connect to only 1 EC2 <-> 1 EC2 can connect to multiple EBS
  • Bound to 1 AZ
  • Billed for provisioned capacity
  • On instance termination
    • root EBS volume of instance is deleted (Default)
    • attached EBS volume is not deleted (Default)

cards.question: EBS Snapshot
cards.answer:
• Create snapshot of EBS at a point in time
  • No need to detach volume, but recommended
  • Can copy across AZ or Region
  • Features
    • Snapshot Archive: Cheaper, take 1-3 days to restore
    • Recycle Bin: recover from accidental deletion (1 day to 1 year)
    • Fast Snapshot Restore: Force full init of snapshot to EBS volume (Expensive)

cards.question: EBS Volume Types
cards.answer:
Type Storage Base IOPS
Max IOPS		 Throughput Boot Volume Muti-Attached Use Case
gp2 General Purpose SSD 1 GiB - 16 TiB

3 IOPs per GB
(depends on storage size)

16,000 IOPS

 250 MB/s Yes No

General Purpose

Balanced workload
gp3

3,000 IOPS
(independent of storage size)

16,000 IOPS 

 1,000 MB/s
io1 Provisioned IOPS SSD 4 GiB - 16 TiB

Provisioned by user

64,000 IOPS
(50 IOPS/GB)

 1,000 MB/s Yes Yes

Mission-critical database

High & consistent IOPs
io2 Block Express 4 GiB - 64 TiB

Provisioned by user

64,000 IOPS
(500 IOPS/GB)

 1,000 MB/s
st1 Throughput Optimized HDD 125 GiB -
16 TiB		 500 IOPS 500 MB/s No No

Big Data

Log Processing
sc1 Cold HDD 250 IOPS 250 MB/s

Infrequent Access

Backup Data

cards.question: EBS Multi-Attach
cards.answer:
• Normally: 1 EBS connect to 1 EC2
  • Multi-Attach: 1EBS connect to multiple EC2
  • Only for EBS io1 or io2
  • EC2 instances in same AZ

cards.question: EBS Encryption
cards.answer:
• Encrypted EBS Volume:
    • Encrypted data at rest inside EBS Volume
    • Encrypted data in transit
    • Encrypted snapshots
    • Encrypted volumes created from snapshot
  • Cannot directly encrypt an unecrypted EBS Volume
    1. Create snapshot of unencrypted volume
    2. Encrypt the copy of snapshot
    3. Create new volume using encrypted snapshot
    4. New volume is now encrypted

cards.question: EFS Performance
cards.answer:
• 1000s of concurrent NFS Clients
  • 10 GB+/s throughput
  • Grow to Petabyte-scale network automatically
  • Performance: (set at creation, cannot change)
    • General Purpose: low latency (web server)
    • Max I/O: highly parallel but higher latency (big data)
  • Throughput: (can change)
    • Bursting: 50 MiB/s + burst up to 100 MiB/s 
      • Only pay for storage size
    • Provisioned: set throughput regardless of storage size
      • pay for provisioned amount
    • Elastic: Automatically scales throughput (unpredictable workload)
      • pay based on actual throughput used

cards.question: EFS Storage Class
cards.answer:
• Storage Tiers
    • Standard
    • Infrequent Access
    • Archive
    • can implement lifecycle policies 
  • Availability
    • Standard: Multi-AZ (best for prod)
    • One Zone: One AZ (best for dev)

cards.question: Elastic File System (EFS)
cards.answer:
• Managed Network File System
  • Works with EC2 instances in multi-AZ
  • NFSv4.1 protocol
  • Pay per use
  • POSIX file system (Linux)
  • Compatible with Linux based AMI
  • Higher cost compared to EBS

cards.question: Elastic Load Balancer (ELB)
cards.answer:
• Managed Load Balancer
  • Spread load across multiple downstream
  • Expose single point of access (DNS)
  • Health checks
  • Provide SSL termination
  • Enforce stickiness with cookie
  • High availability across multiple AZs
  • Separate public and private traffic

cards.question: ELB Health Checks
cards.answer:
• Check if instance is healthy
  • Check on both port and route (e.g. /health)
  • response: 200 (OK)

cards.question: ELB Types of load balancer
cards.answer:
• Application Load Balancer (ALB)
    • HTTP, HTTPS, WebSocket
  • Network Load Balancer (NLB)
    • TCP, TLS, UDP
  • Gateway Load Balancer (GLB)
    • Network Layer - IP Protocol

cards.question: HTTP vs WebSocket
cards.answer:
HTTP/HTTPS WebSocket
Communication Request-Response only Full-duplex
Connection 1 request = 1 connection Single long-lived connection
Overhead High (HTTP header per request) Low (After initial handshake)
Real-time Poor Excellent
Use Cases Webpage Live chat

cards.question: Application Load Balancer (ALB)
cards.answer:
• Level 7 (HTTP)
  • Support HTTP & WebSocket
  • Support redirects ( HTTP -> HTTPS)
  • Health check configured at target group level
  • Load Balance
    • To multiple HTTP applications across machines
    • To multiple applications on same machine (different port)
  • Routing method
    • Path in URL (example.com/users & example.com/posts)
    • hostname in URL (one.example.com & other.example.com)
    • Query String, Headers (example.com/users?id=123&order=false)
  • Target Groups (ALB can route to multiple target groups)
    • EC2 instance - HTTP
    • ECS task - HTTP
    • Lambda - HTTP request translated to JSON event
    • IP Address - Private IP
  • Provide a DNS name for client to point to (e.g. XXX.region.elb.amazonaws.com)
  • Does not show client's real IP (ALB acts as proxy)
  • ALB inserts client's IP into HTTP header X-Forwarded-For
  • X-Forwarded-Port = Port, X-Forwarded-Proto = Protocol

cards.question: Network Load Balancer (NLB)
cards.answer:
• Forward TCP & UDP traffic
  • Ultra-low latency
  • One Static IP per AZ, support assigning Elastic IP
  • Supported Healthcheck protocol: TCP,HTTP,HTTPS
  • Target Groups
    • EC2 instances
    • Private IP addresses

cards.question: Gateway Load Balancer (GWLB)
cards.answer:
• Operate at Level 3 (Network Layer)
  • Use GENEVE protocol on port 6081
  • Transparently insert third-party app
    • E.g. packet inspection tools, intrusion detection, firewall
    • Divert traffic to 3rd party instead of using 3rd party to sniff, man-in-the-middle
    • After inspection, data is sent back to GWLB
    • GWLB then send data back to intended destination
  • Target Groups
    • EC2 instances
    • Private IP addresses

cards.question: ALB Sticky Sessions
cards.answer:
• Allow client to always redirect to same instance behind load balancer
  • Works for ALB
  • May bring imbalance to load of EC2 instances
  • To minimise impact, use sticky session only when
    • App is stateful
    • Session is short-lived
  • Types of cookies
    • Application-based Custom Cookies
      • Generated by target
      • Include any custom attribute by the app
      • Cookie name per target group
      • Cannot use name AWSALB, AWSALBAPP
    • Application cookie
      • Generated by ALB
      • Cookie values - session, users, etc.
      • App that doesnt want to change application logic to handle sticky session
      • Stable identifier (valid until browser delete, set custome expiration)
      • Cookie name is AWSALBAPP
    • Duration-based Cookies
      • Generatd by ALB
      • Has TTL in seconds
      • Cookie name is AWSALB

cards.question: ELB SSL Certificates
cards.answer:
• Uses X.509 certificates (SSL/TLS server certificate)
  • manage using ACM (AWS Certificate Manager)
  • Can create/upload own certificates
  • Acts as HTTPS listener:
    • Specify default certificate
    • Can add optional list certs for supporting multiple domains
      • example.com, api.example.com
    • Client can use SNI to specify hostname they want to reach
    • Ability to choose security policies to support older SSL/TLS versions

cards.question: SSL Server Name Indicator (SNI)
cards.answer:
• Server can have multiple websites/domain on same IP address
  • But needs to know which certificate to present to user
  • Example
    • example.com uses Certificate A
    • api.example.com uses Certificate B
    • client tells ALB -> Connect to api.example.com -> ALB returns Certificate B

cards.question: ELB Deregistration Delay
cards.answer:
1. For ALB & NLB
  2. ELB receive signal to deregister a target
    • Manual deregistration
    • Auto Scaling Group scale in
    • Unhealthy instance
  3. ELB marks the target as "draining"
    • Stop sending new connections
  4. ELB waits for the deregistration delay period
    • existing connection allowed to complete
  5. ELB fully deregisters the target
    • Remove target from target group
    • Does not wait for instance to complete
    • If instance cannot complete in time ->workload is lost

cards.question: ASG Attributes
cards.answer:
• Launch Template/Launch Config
    • AMI & Instance Type
    • EC2 User Data
    • EBS Volume
    • Security Groups
    • SSH Key Pair
    • IAM Roles of EC2 instance
    • Network & Subnets information
    • Load balancer information
  • Min Size/ Max Size/ Capacity
  • Scaling Policies

cards.question: ASG Scaling Policies
cards.answer:
1. Simple Scaling
    • One action per alarm (Single Step)
    • e.g. CPU>70% ->add 1 instance
  2. Step Scaling
    • Multiple actions per alarm
    • More granular control
    • e.g. CPU >70% -> add 1 instance
    • CPU >85% -> add 2 instances
  3. Target Tracking Scaling
    • Track metric
    • ASG scale in/out automatically
    • Slight delay ( ASG follows metric)
    • e.g. Keep avg CPU at 60%
  4. Scheduled Scaling
    • Set instance sizes based on time
    • No delay
    • For predicatable workload
    • Non dynamic (fixed pattern)
    • e.g. 9am-5pm ->10 instances
      5pm-9am -> 4 instances
  5. Predictive Scaling
    • Use ML to forecast
    • Require 1-2 days of historical data
    • For predicatable workload
    • Dynamic
    • No delay (predict workload)

cards.question: ASG Scaling Group Comparision
cards.answer:
• Simple/Step Scaling
    • More control
    • Fixed pattern
    • More setup required
  • Target-Tracking Scaling
    • Dynamic
    • Slight delay (follow metrics)
    • For less predictable workload 
    • Almost no setup required
  • Scheduled Scaling
    • More control
    • Fixed pattern
    • Based on time
    • For predictable workload
    • More setup required
  • Predictive Scaling
    • Leverage ML
    • No delay
    • For predicatable workload
    • Need 1-2 days of historical data

cards.question: ASG Metrics
cards.answer:
• Metrics to scale on
    • CPUUtilization: Avg CPU ultilization across all instances
    • RequesCountPerTarget: Avg number of request per instance
    • AverageNetworkIn/Out: Avg network in/out of instance (if app is network-bound)
    • Custom Metrics

cards.question: EC2 Spot Instance
cards.answer:
Request:

  1. Define max spot price
  2. get spot instance when current spot price < max
  3. if current spot price > max -> can choose to stop/terminate

Use Case: batch job, data analysis, failure-resilient workload

Cancelling a spot request doesnt terminate instance, only stop AWS from launching more instance

cards.question: IAM Roles
cards.answer: • Allows AWS services to perform actions

cards.question: Elastic Network Interface (ENI)
cards.answer:
• Virtual Network Card
  • Attributes:
    • Primary private IPv4, one or more secondary IPv4
    • One Elastic IPv4 per private IPv4
    • One Public IPv4
    • One or more Security Groups
    • MAC Address
  • Can be indepently created
  • Can be moved between different EC2

cards.question: Auto Scaling Group (ASG)
cards.answer:
• Scale out: Increase EC2 instances
  • Scale in: Decrease ECS instances
  • Use metrics from Cloudwatch to scale
  • Ensure minimum and maximum number of EC2 instances
  • Automatically register instances to load balancer
  • Create EC2 instances when old one is terminated
  • Scaling Cooldowns:
    • Set cooldown period
    • Default cooldown (300 seconds)
    • ASG will not scale during this time
    • Allow metrics to stabilize
  • Instance Warm-ups:
    • Set warm-up delay
    • Delay to make sure instance is ready
    • if delay is not over, the instance is not accounted into metric
  • Free (only pay for underlying EC2 instances)

cards.question: ASG Launch Template VS Launch Configuration
cards.answer:
Feature Launch Template Launch Configuration (Legacy)
Immutability Versioned
(Can create new version)		 Immutable
(Need to create new launch config)
Use Case For all new ASGs Basic ASG, legacy system
Spot Instances & Mixed Instance Support spot options,
mixed instance policy		 No
Multiple Network Interface Yes No
Advanced EC2 features Yes No
Modify user data Yes No

cards.question: Relational Database Service (RDS)
cards.answer:
• Managed DB service for SQL
    • Automated provisioning
    • Point in Time Recovery
    • Monitoring dashboard
    • Read Replicas
    • Multi AZ
    • Scaling capability (vertical & horizontal)
    • Data stored in EBS thats managed by RDS
    • User cannot access underlying EBS, only through endpoint
    • BUT cannot SSH into it
  • Supported database:
    • Postgres
    • MySQL
    • MariaDB
    • Orable
    • Microsoft SQL Server
    • IBM DB2
    • Aurora

cards.question: RDS Storage Auto Scaling
cards.answer:
• Automatically increase storage size
  • NOT enabled by default
  • Set Maximum Storage Threshold (max storage to scale to)
  • Only scale up
  • Auto-scaling condition
    • Free storage <10%
    • Last at least 5 minutes
    • 6 hours cooldown period
  • For unpredicatble workload

cards.question: RDS Read Replica
cards.answer:
• Max 15 Read Replicas
  • Can be within AZ, Cross AZ, Cross Region
  • ASYNC replication (Eventually consistent)
  • Can be promoted to fully DB instance
    • Once promoted, it works as another DB, no longer linked to old DB
    • e.g. Disaster Recovery, Dev, etc.
  • Cost
    • Storage Cost: Same as primary DB instance
    • Network Cost: (Data transfer)
      • Same AZ: Free
      • Cross AZ: Charged
      • Cross Region: Charged

cards.question: RDS Multi AZ
cards.answer:
• Disaster Recovery
  • 1 primary instance + 1 standby instance
  • Expose only 1 DNS name for automatic failover
  • If primary instance fail, it will promote standby into primary instance
  • SYNC Replication
  • Increase Availability
  • Turning Single AZ to Multi AZ:
    • Zero downtime (just click 'Modify')
    • Internal process
      1. Snapshot taken
      2. New DB restored from snapshot in new AZ
      3. Synchronization between 2 DB

cards.question: RDS Custom
cards.answer:
• Managed database with OS and database customization
  • Supported Database:
    • Oracle
    • Microsoft SQL Server Database
  • Allows:
    • Configure settings
    • Install patches
    • Enable native features
    • Access underlying EC2 instance using SSH or SSM Session Manager
  • Deactivate Automation Mode to perform customization

cards.question: Aurora High Availability and Read Scaling
cards.answer:
• Aurora stores data in storage replicas (not read replicas)
    • Shared storage volume
    • Not a separate instance like read replica
    • Free
  • 6 copies of data in 3 AZ
    • 2 copies in each AZ
    • Self-healing
  • Quorum-based (require multiple copies to agree)
    • Write: 4 out of 6
    • Read: 3 out of 6

cards.question: Aurora
cards.answer:
• Cloud Optimized
  • Supported SQL:
    • MySQL
    • Postgres
  • Auto scaling storage
    • Increment of 10GB
    • Max 128 TB
  • DB Cluster
    • 1 writer (master)
    • Read replicas:
      • Max: 15 replicas
      • Can be cross region
  • Instanteneous failover: Highly available
  • More expensive than RDS

cards.question: Aurora Endpoints
cards.answer:
Type Route to Use Case
Writer Primary writer instance Writes and lastest data
Reader All available read replica instance
Load balancing to choose only one

Eventually consistent data
High load
Custom Can specify subset of instances Specialized workload
Analytics

cards.question: Aurora Serverless
cards.answer:
• Auto provision of DB instance
  • Automatically adjust compute
  • Pay based on actual usage
  • Use case:
    • Infrequent
    • Unpredicatble workload
  • No capacity planning needed
  • More expensive for sustained workload compared to Aurora

cards.question: Aurora Global Database
cards.answer:
• 1 Primary region (write/read)
  • Up to 5 secondary read-only region
  • replication lag < 1 sec
  • Up to 16 read replicas
  • Can promote primary to another region with RTO < 1 min
  • Cross-region replication < 1 sec
  • Use case
    • Global apps
    • Mission-critical
    • Strict data recovery

cards.question: Aurora Machine Learning
cards.answer:
• Integrate Aurora queries directly with AWS ML services
  • ML-based predictions via SQL
  • Supported Services
    • SageMaker
    • Comprehend
  • Use case:
    • Fraud detection
    • Ads targeting
    • setiment analysis

cards.question: RDS vs Aurora Backups
cards.answer:
RDS Aurora
Automated backup

Daily full backup of database
Transaction logs backup every 5 mins
Restore point in time
1-35 days of retention
Can be disable 

Daily full backup of database
Transaction logs backup real-time
1-35 days of retention
Cannot be disable
Manual DB snapshot Manually triggered
Retention: until user delete		 Manually triggered
Retention: until user delete

cards.question: RDS & Aurora Restore Option
cards.answer:
• Note: pay for stopped RDS/Aurora instance
  • If not use, snapshot & restore at later date
  • Restore Options:
    1. Restore RDS/Aurora from backup or snapshot
    2. Restore MySQL RDS from S3 (on-prem database)
      • Create backup of on-prem database
      • Store it on S3
      • Restore onto new RDS instance
    3. Restore MySQL Aurora from S3(on-prem database)
      • Create backup of on-prem database using Percona XtraBackup
      • Store it on S3
      • Restore onto new Aurora cluster

cards.question: Aurora Database Cloning
cards.answer:
• Create new DB from existing DB
  • Faster than snapshot & restore
  • Use Copy-On-Write Protocol
    • At cloning time: Original DB & clone DB share same data storage
    • After cloning: only modified data pages get copied and stored separately

cards.question: RDS & Aurora Security
cards.answer:
• At-rest encryption:
    • Database master & replicas encryption using AWS KMS
    • If master is not encrypted -> read replica cannot be encrypted
      • Need to restore DB snapshot as encrypted
  • In-flight encryption:
    • TLS-ready by default, use the AWS TLS root certificates client-side
  • No SSH available except on RDS Custom
  • Audit Logs can be enabled and sent to CloudWatch Logs for longer retention

cards.question: RDS Proxy
cards.answer:
• Managed database proxy for RDS/Aurora
  • Connection pooling
    • Reuse and shares DB Connection
    • Reduce latency
    • Reduce resource consumption
    • Reduce failover time
  • RDS Proxy is never publicly accessible (must be accessed from VPC)

cards.question: ElastiCache
cards.answer:
• In-memory database
  • Reduce load of databases for read intensive workload
  • Enhance serverless architecture
  • Requires code changes to integrate caching
  • App is responsible for managing data in cache 
  • Database Caching
    • App queries from ElastiCache, if not available, query from DB and store in Elasticache
    • Must have invalidation strategy to only keep most current data
  • User Session Store
    • App writes session data into ElastiCache
    • App retrieve data from ElastiCache
  • Caching Strategies
    • Lazy Loading
      • If data in cache, read it, else, read from DB
      • Stale data, existing data is always used (not updated)
    • Write Through
      • Add data to cache when app perform write on DB
      • Write overhead, writing becomes 2 step process
    • Session Store
      • Set TTL on data to keep freshness
      • Premature expiration can occue

cards.question: ElastiCache
cards.answer:
Redis Memcached
Data Structure Advanced (list, strings, etc)  Simple Key-Value
Multi-AZ with Auto-Failover Yes No
Data Durability Yes (Using Append-Only File to store all write operations and replay AOF) No
Performance Slow Fast
Use Case Live leaderboard
Session Management
Real-time Analytics		 Simple caching
Caching static content

cards.question: EC2 Amazon Machine Image (AMI)
cards.answer:
• Pre-configured template of EC2
  • Golden AMI: standardized and curated AMI to use for consistent production
  • Region-scoped (can be copied across region)
  • Source
    • Public AMI (AWS AMI)
    • Custom AMI
    • AWS Marketplace AMI
  • Process
    1. Start EC2 instance
    2. Stop instance
    3. build AMI
    4. Launch new instance using AMI

cards.question: Route 53
cards.answer:
• Fully managed Domain Name Server (DNS)
  • Provide health checks for resources
  • Authoritative
    • Contain all DNS records for domain names within a domain
    • Provide the final IP address if non-authoritative DNS server cannot find

cards.question: Route 53 Record Types
cards.answer:
• A: Maps to IPv4
    • 192.0.2.1
  • AAAA: Maps to IPv6
    • 2001:db8::1
  • CNAME: Maps to other domain/subdomain names
    • Domain name of DNS record cannot be top-level domain 
    • Name Type Value Allowed
      www.example.com CNAME example.com Yes
      example.com CNAME www.example.com No (top-level can only have A, AAAA, NS)
  • NS: Maps to Name Servers for the Hosted Zone
    • Authoritative DNS server name assigned to serve the zone
    • Automatically assigned and managed by AWS
  • Example
    • Name Type Value TTL
      example.com A 192.0.2.1 300
      example.com AAAA 2001:db8::1 300
      www.example.com CNAME example.com 300
      example.com NS ns-123.awsdns-45.com. -

cards.question: Route 53 DNS Records
cards.answer:
• Contains
    • Domain/Subdomain name:
      • Domain: hostnamee.g. example.com
      • Subdomain: e.g. api.example.com
    • Record Type: A, AAAA, CNAME, NS
    • Value: IPv4, IPv6, domain/subdomain names
    • Routing Policy
    • TTL: Required (except for NS record type)

cards.question: Route 53 Hosted Zone
cards.answer:
• Container for records of specific domain
  • Contain all DNS records related to domain and its subdomain
  • Public Hosted Zone
    • Manage DNS records for domain accessible over the public internet
    • Publicly resolvable worldwide
  • Private Hosted Zone
    • Manage DNS records for domain within one or more VPC
    • Only resolvable within VPC

cards.question: Route 53 CNAME vs Alias
cards.answer:
CNAME

  •  Maps subdomain to another domain name (not IP address)
  • Can only be used on subdomain

ALIAS

  • Maps domain/subdomain name to AWS resources
  • Can be used on domain & subdomain
  • Use record types (A or AAAA)
  • Automatically assigned by AWS
  • Can only point to AWS managed resources
    • EC2 doesnt have stable DNS name
